docs.lead_paragraph: One day soon, perhaps as soon as a few years, many diabetics may forever throw away the lancets they use to prick their fingers for blood sugar tests and the needles they use to inject themselves with insulin. Instead, they may be wearing bracelets or even earrings smart enough to sense and report glucose levels continuously to an artificial pancreas: a surgically embedded pump that dispenses just the right amount of insulin into their bloodstreams.

headline.main: Better Care of Diabetics, and Less Pain

docs.abstract: Researchers say that development of artificial pancreas is becoming more plausible, and would be a major breakthrough in treatment of diabetes; pancreas helps regulate blood sugar levels by producing insulin; description of various glucose monitors; photos (M)
docs.snippet: One day soon, perhaps as soon as a few years, many diabetics may forever throw away the lancets they use to prick their fingers for blood sugar tests and the needles they use to inject themselves with insulin.    Instead, they may be wearing...

docs.lead_paragraph: Secondhand cigarette smoke may be more dangerous than previously believed, according to researchers, who report that some women with a common gene mutation are as much as six times as likely to develop lung cancer if they live with smokers. An examination of tissue from a group of Missouri women who lived with smokers found that those with the mutation, which involves the absence of a gene, were 2.6 to 6 times as likely to develop lung cancer as those who did not live with smokers, the researchers reported last week.
docs.abstract: Researchers find that secondhand cigarette smoke may be more dangerous than previously believed; report that some women with a common gene mutation are as much as six times as likely to develop lung cancer if they live with smokers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a recent issue, The Harvard Medical Alumni Bulletin asked graduates what music they listened to when they operated. Some answers follow. At my hospital, classical music tends to predominate, although the gynecologists seem to like soft rock. One surgeon likes to play the Grateful Dead during operations in the middle of the night; the best I can say about that music is that it helps keep me awake.

headline.main: What Your Surgeon Hums When You're Not Listening

docs.abstract: Graduates of Harvard Medical School describe what music they listen to when they operate; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, the solutions to the most serious medical problems do not have to be high tech. A recent study published in The Lancet suggests that to reduce pneumonia in intensive-care wards, all doctors need to do is to have the patients sit up.

headline.main: A Low-Tech Way to Prevent Pneumonia

docs.abstract: Study of patients in intensive-care wards finds that having them lie on their backs appears to contribute to development of pneumonia, and that doctors should have their patients sit up to reduce cases of pneumonia (S)
docs.snippet: Sometimes, the solutions to the most serious medical problems do not have to be high tech.    A recent study published in The Lancet suggests that to reduce pneumonia in intensive-care wards, all doctors need to do is to have the patients sit up.

docs.lead_paragraph: No parent shells out the money for ballet class so a child can turn out a flat-footed dancer, but keeping dancers off their toes may not be such a bad thing, at least for a while. A new study suggests that going on point may lead to arthritis of the ankle in ballet dancers. The research was presented last week at a conference of the Radiological Society of North America.

headline.main: When on Their Toes Means at Some Risk

docs.abstract: New study suggests that going on point may lead to arthritis of ankle in ballet dancers; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Grown-ups say the darnedest things when trying to comfort the bereaved. Consider the following, compiled from books on mourning and from personal experience: To a 60-year-old recent widow: ''Don't worry. You're young and attractive; you'll find someone else.''

headline.main: Mourning, a Time When Words Often Fail

docs.abstract: First of two columns by Jane E Brody on bereavement; guidelines on what to say, and what not to say, to those in mourning (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The physical sensation is fleeting, but the emotional trauma can linger for months. And in the worst cases, the physical harm can be lifelong, or even fatal. Health care workers call it the needle stick, and for many it is their greatest fear on the job, because one small slip could infect them with H.I.V., hepatitis or a similar cause of disease. Each year, federal authorities estimate, there are 600,000 to 800,000 such mistakes among the nation's eight million health care workers, although most do not result in infection.
docs.abstract: National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health issues guidelines meant to reduce risk of needle-stick injuries to health workers; for medical workers, greatest risk comes if they stick themselves with a needle used on patient with hepatitis B; chance of infection is as high as 30 percent (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For many women who need to undergo hysterectomies, the anxiety they feel is not just over the surgery to remove the uterus but over a widespread belief about the procedure's aftermath: that their sex lives will never be the same. Now, a study of 1,300 women by the University of Maryland medical school may put that fear to rest. It reports that most women said their sex lives were better, not worse, after the operation, which is performed on 600,000 women in America each year, mainly those who suffer the benign but painful uterine tumors called fibroids.
docs.abstract: Study of 1,300 women who underwent hysterectomies finds that most say their sex lives were better, not worse, after operation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, federal officials said the Clinton administration might soon issue sweeping new rules for the workplace that could help protect millions of Americans from repetitive strain injuries, often associated with the heavy use of computers. Under the new rules, employers with even a few cases of R.S.I. will be required to carry out full-scale ergonomic programs. Now a new study raises questions about the best way to diagnose one of the best-known R.S.I. diseases, carpal tunnel syndrome.

headline.main: A Different Way to Gauge Carpal Tunnel

docs.abstract: New study raises questions about best way to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome, one of best-known repetitive strain injuries; study finds that variations in results of nerve-conduction studies often used to make a finding of carpal tunnel are so significant that there should be changes in how they are interpreted (S)
docs.snippet: Two weeks ago, federal officials said the Clinton administration might soon issue sweeping new rules for the workplace that could help protect millions of Americans from repetitive strain injuries, often associated with the heavy use of computers....

docs.lead_paragraph: It was probably inevitable that the World Wide Web would bloom with sites for dieters. But to the surprise of professional dietitians, many of these sites have turned out to be not only popular but effective. From fee-based ventures like eDiets.com to free ones like Cyberdiet.com, a cornucopia of sites has sprung up in the last year or two to provide nutrition and diet advice. Many offer services that are otherwise found through private dietitians or diet companies like Weight Watchers, including personalized feedback and support from a group of fellow dieters.

headline.main: Losing Pounds by Surfing, on the Web

docs.abstract: Comment on dieting sites that have sprung up on World Wide Web; among most aggressive commercial dieting sites is eDiets.com; site offers advice on nutrition, exercise and motivation for a fee; photo (M)
